content.text: * Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
* Faculty conducting the course: Information Technology; Room 1310, Building A1, National Economics University; Phone number: 024.36280.280 (6334; 6324)
1. Nguyen Trung Kien, MSc. Tel: 0988740189 Email: kiennt@neu.edu.vn
2. Dang Minh Quan PhD. Tel: 0974821967 Email: quandm@neu.edu.vn
* Meeting hour: 8AM – 11AM on Wednesdays, Room 1310, Building A1, National Economics University

The operating systems course is intended as a general introduction to the techniques used to deploy operating systems, the types of system software involved, and the historical development of operating systems. This course consists of: (1) Operating system function, structure, service (2) Process and Thread management (states, creation, synchronization, and communication); Process scheduling (short-term, long-term, medium-term); prevent, avoid and overcome deadlocks; (3) Main memory management; virtual memory management (swapping, paging, segmentation, and page replacement algorithms); (4) Mass storage and disk management; (5) File system structure and implementation; (6) I/O devices and peripheral; (7) Protection and Security.
* Text Books: Abraham Silberschatz, Peter B. Galvin, Greg Gagne; Operating System Concepts; 10th Edition, Wiley.

cells: - To explain main components and functions of OS and their working. -To familiarize the operations performed by OS as a resource Manager - To deal with IPC and synchronization -To teach the different memory management techniques. - Operating principles and functions of basic operating system components such as process management, disk management, file management, import/export management - Organize system protection and information security - Research specifically on some Windows and UNIX operating systems

column_map.Goals Description: - To explain main components and functions of OS and their working. -To familiarize the operations performed by OS as a resource Manager - To deal with IPC and synchronization -To teach the different memory management techniques. - Operating principles and functions of basic operating system components such as process management, disk management, file management, import/export management - Organize system protection and information security - Research specifically on some Windows and UNIX operating systems

cells: The module guides learners in the skills to handle professional situations in a systematic way. Students know how to coordinate with each other to solve a professional problem on time.

cells: The course contributes to developing the ability to solve problems independently as well as the ability to work in groups to jointly solve professional problems. Initially equipping learners with awareness of the social context, professional ethics, and social responsibility in the IT field.

column_map.Teaching-learning activities: Students take exams according to given schedule

content.text: Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).

Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
Students will be awarded points for constructive comments these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.

Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.

full_text:
* Title: OPERATING SYSTEM
* Code: CNTT1107
* Credits: 03 (45 hours)
* Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
+ Lecture: 25 hrs
+ Exercises on class: 10 hrs
+ Presentation and Discussion: 10 hrs
+ Exercise and discussion: 10 hrs
+ Field work: ....... hrs
+ Self-study: 10 hrs.
* Parallel course(s): None
* Prerequisite course(s): CNTT1116
* Faculty conducting the course: Information Technology; Room 1310, Building A1, National Economics University; Phone number: 024.36280.280 (6334; 6324)
+ Lecturers:
1. Nguyen Trung Kien, MSc. Tel: 0988740189 Email: kiennt@neu.edu.vn
2. Dang Minh Quan PhD. Tel: 0974821967 Email: quandm@neu.edu.vn
* Kind of the course:
* Course language: In English
* Meeting hour: 8AM – 11AM on Wednesdays, Room 1310, Building A1, National Economics University
The operating systems course is intended as a general introduction to the techniques used to deploy operating systems, the types of system software involved, and the historical development of operating systems. This course consists of: (1) Operating system function, structure, service (2) Process and Thread management (states, creation, synchronization, and communication); Process scheduling (short-term, long-term, medium-term); prevent, avoid and overcome deadlocks; (3) Main memory management; virtual memory management (swapping, paging, segmentation, and page replacement algorithms); (4) Mass storage and disk management; (5) File system structure and implementation; (6) I/O devices and peripheral; (7) Protection and Security.
* Text Books: Abraham Silberschatz, Peter B. Galvin, Greg Gagne; Operating System Concepts; 10th Edition, Wiley.
* Additional references:
Table 4. Course goals
Table 5. Course learning outcomes (CLOs)
* Assessment methods:
- Grading: 10
- Average score of course is the total points of rubrics multiplied by the respective weight of each rubric.
* Assessment summary:
Table 6. Assessment summary
* Rubrics:
Rubric 1: Participant
Rubric 2: Individual tests
Rubric 3: Group works
Rubric 4: Final exam
Table 7. Course outline
Table 8.1. Lesson plan for the course
9.1. Requirements for taking final /terminal exams
Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).
9.2. Requirements for attending classes
Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
Students will be awarded points for constructive comments these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
9.3. Requirements for in-class behaviour
The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.
Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.
